qas.question: Ring-porous hardwoods have a clear relationship between their properties and what other factor?
Is harder, heavier wood indicated by narrower or wider growth rings?
What kind of wood with a name that starts with "H" is a ring-porous hardwood?
If the growth rings are wider, was the growth of the tree slower or more rapid?
What is the only kind of wood that will definitely be harder and stronger when it grows faster?

context: In the case of the ring-porous hardwoods there seems to exist a pretty definite relation between the <a0_0>rate of growth<a0_0/> of timber and its properties. This may be briefly summed up in the general statement that the <a3_0>more rapid<a3_0/> the growth or the <a1_0>wider<a1_0/> the rings of growth, the heavier, harder, stronger, and stiffer the wood. This, it must be remembered, applies only to <a4_0>ring-porous<a4_0/> woods such as oak, ash, <a2_0>hickory<a2_0/>, and others of the same group, and is, of course, subject to some exceptions and limitations.
